Award.AwardTitle: EAGER Proposal for a Teacher's Guide to the Mathematics and Science Resources of the ELPD Framework

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Council of Chief State School Officers (CCSSO) coordinated the development of a document addressing the implementation of Standards as guided by a framework for English Language Proficiency Development Standards (ELPD Framework). The expressed purpose of the ELPD Framework is to provide guidance to states on how to develop and use tools for the creation and evaluation of ELP standards. Once published, it became immediately apparent that the ELPD Framework would be of great help to teachers. However, the Framework was written specifically for those tasked with the responsibility to develop, adopt, or adapt state ELPD standards and assessments that support the language demands of STEM education grounded in learning performances that cojoin concepts with practices. That is, it has a technical focus rather than an instructional focus. There is an immediate need to develop and validate such a tool in states that have adopted Standards-based models, since educational agencies are now building teachers capacities to implement these standards.

This two-year project will develop, pilot, validate, and publish a Teacher?s Guide to the Science and Mathematics Resources of the ELPD Framework. This guide and related materials will translate the key science and mathematics concepts, ideas, and practices found within the ELPD Framework into classroom resources for direct use by teachers, schools, and districts to support English learners (ELs).

Resources supporting ELs at different language proficiency levels in science and mathematics classrooms are sparse. Classroom-based resources supporting ELs? academic language development in science and mathematics based on career and college readiness standards are non-existent. The development of such a resource would have significant impact on science and mathematics teachers? teaching of ELs. Understanding how teachers? practice in supporting content-based academic language changes by using such a resource would be of great value for teachers, administrators, and researchers. Arguably, the ELPD Framework (and the proposed teacher?s guide) has applications beyond ELs. Many challenges ?at-risk? students face in science and mathematics classes may not be due to a lack in content knowledge, per se, but a lack of ability to communicate in the ?language? of the content. The proposed teacher?s guide could help teachers support all students in the language underlying the science and mathematics standards in the CCSS and NGSS.

POR.DRECONTENT:
STEM education has not been sufficiently effective for the nation’s most rapidly growing K-12 subgroup: English Learners (ELs), who lag behind in STEM achievement and are under-represented in STEM careers. The adoption of the CCSS and NGSS offers the potential to increase national science literacy, support critical learning of 21st century skills, and open pathways to stable and important STEM careers. Yet, these standards also require students to use language in increasingly sophisticated ways to explain and critique complex concepts, and come at a time when educators continue to  feel ill-prepared to teach ELs. The promise of the CCSS and NGSS for this rapidly growing segment of our nation can only be realized if ELs are given equitable opportunities to engage deeply with STEM content and practices.

This grant’s goal was to develop generative resources to increase EL engagement in STEM, particularly in the science and engineering practices and the mathematical practices. Consultation with experts, a literature review, and observations conducted as part of the project’s case study indicated the need to address three common problems of practice:

  1. Observed classroom interaction patterns did not engage students in STEM disciplinary practices, and were not focused on the critical thinking embedded in the practices, but consisted of repetitive teacher-single student interchanges to elicit 1-2 word responses to questions, and focused correctness rather than the elicitation or deepening of student reasoning;
  2. In collaborative groups, student discourse was directed to task accomplishment, rather than reasoning, and ELs, in particular, were either excluded or placed in the role of listener.
  3. Language development for ELs was viewed primarily as vocabulary instruction. There was little focus on developing ELs’ language for collaborative reasoning and the expression of complex ideas.

Teachers needed increased awareness of STEM disciplinary practices, and means of shifting instruction to emphasize the academic discourse of reasoning and critical thinking, and these resources had to support ELs’ effective engagement as meaning-makers alongside their English-fluent peers. Concomitantly, students needed resources to support the desired focus on reasoning and explanation.

This grant’s major activities were to:

  1. develop a suite of generative resources to support teachers’ enactment of STEM disciplinary practices, particularly those involving collaborative reasoning and analysis, as well as student resources to support ELs’ engagement with their peers in the critical academic discourse of the STEM practices;
  2.  revise the resources based on findings of an implementation case study (grades 4 and 7, math and science);
  3. provide implementation support and open access to the full suite of generative resources through a project website.

 

After engaging national experts in science and math education and second language acquisition and conducting preliminary classroom observations, the project team created a set of resources. Teacher Discourse Moves provided scaffolds for probing and strengthening students’ reasoning, while Student Discourse Moves offered students both a meta-cognitive framework to track the logic of developing ideas and sentence frames at three levels of English proficiency for questioning, probing, and challenging ideas, and for explaining and justifying their reasoning. Case studies and interviews one year later indicated greatly increased involvement of ELs in the academic discourse of their classrooms, as well as teacher satisfaction regarding the acceptance of ELs into the classroom discourse community. Additionally, teachers reported that all students were more engaged, were ‘digging into’ challenges in ways that they had not before, and teachers were more confident of all students’ understanding of content and concepts. 

The full suite of materials is now available on the project website (http://stem4els.wceruw.org). These include 13 video-recordings of students and teachers using the Discourse Moves in science and math classrooms, and of teachers and administrator offering suggestions for implementation of the approach. Downloadable resources offer teachers reflection questions to self-assess and strengthen their practice, and similar reflection questions to help students and student work groups improve their collaborative practice.

National dissemination includes presentations at two annual WIDA conferences (for teachers of ELs), and invited presentations at six national and regional NSTA conferences. Two book chapters have been published or are in press. Project resources have been integrated into multiple professional development offerings and publications by the 39-state WIDA Consortium, and are being used in the California Science Project, and the Multimodal Observation Protocol project at the State University of New York-Albany.

Some suggest that EL disparity in STEM achievement and career choices is not attributable to a leaky pipeline, but to the fact that some students never even enter the pipeline because they do not see themselves as having a place in STEM—a perspective supported by our early classroom observations. To address this inequity, teachers must provide ELs opportunities to engage deeply with their peers in STEM content and practices. These resources offer students historically excluded or marginalized a way to engage as equals in the critical work and discourse of STEM.
